Executives are reaping the benefits of an industry turnaround, angering airline workers.

The chief executive of US Airways, W. Douglas Parker, received salary and bonuses of $5.4 million last year, chalked up gains of $9 million by exercising stock options and still holds options and other stock holdings that are currently valued at roughly $30 million.

The pay package, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, had been widely anticipated by some US Airways workers who are trying to negotiate new contracts for higher pay.

Across the airline industry, executives are reaping the benefits of a nascent turnaround in fortunes as investors bid up airline stocks; most executive pay is tied to stock price. But workers are still largely lagging under concessionary contracts, and anger is rising.
The stock price of US Airways has tripled since its 2005 merger with America West Airlines. The shares were quoted at $45.34 in late New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday.
Mr. Parker, 45, received a large package of options and stock grants in the merger; much of the roughly $30 million value is from stock or options that have not yet vested.
